title: Humanist
content:
[http://www.fonts.com/content/learning/fontology/level-1/type-anatomy/typ...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317083037/http:/www.fonts.com/content/learning/fontology/level-1/type-anatomy/type-classifications "http://www.fonts.com/content/learning/fontology/level-1/type-anatomy/type-classifications"). In here if you scroll to humanistic, the example he shows had no characteristics of humanistic such as the diagonal stress, crossbar on the e, serifs are more wedge shaped, etc

Is there something I'm missing here or he's just wrong about his exemplar?
author: laasr

comments.content: Sorry about the wedge shaped serif thing I guess that doesn't apply here. Did he mix up old style with humanistic in his exemplar?

Note that it's under _Sans_ and that's pretty much how they're called.

hhp
So are you saying for humanistic sans serif they had a more vertical stress and so on which were entirely different to how the serifs were done ?

I guess the standards are lower, especially in the context of grots.

hhp
